content.description: Start is the same as West Face route but heads left at the horizontal. The crux is at the two bolts in the headwall.  Good pro with a little spice after the two bolts.
content.protection: Two bolts standard rack of single pieces.
content.location: Same start as West Face Route which starts in a small corner crack system in the middle of the narrow west face.

content.description: Moves up a short crack/corner then right to a bolt then back left to shallow corner.  Powerful moves get you past the bolt.  An old school run out gets you to the ledge and a belay.  from here move right and turn the roof.  Modern cams will make this a bit safer or a .5 tricam.
content.location: Clmbs the west face of the Sphinx and moves right at the horizontal to a bolt at a bulge.

content.description: A must do for the Tucson trad climber.  A little fuzzy right now but with a bit more traffic and some buffing by Jimbo ha ha it will be sweet.  Only two bolts on this route, one before and one at the crux.  The gear on this route is great and the climbing really good all the way to the chains.
content.protection: 2 bolts and a rack of doubles from the little blue micro cams for the start, up to Yellow Camalot size and 1 blue should be enough.
content.location: Main weakness on the left side of the Sphinx.  Climb slab to a small roof 7 feet or so off the ground then into corner then right to bulge with huecos.  Works up between two chossy sections of rock on dark brown rock then moves into the crack system.

climbs.name: Never Again
climbs.fa: Charlie Rollins, Josh Toefield, Kip Metager,'79

content.description: Bulge about 30 feet up is the crux and a green camalot helps and hurts here.  The 5.8 variation keeps moving left here then follows the main weakness and stays left at the top.
content.location: To the right of Cling Tut.  Starts right of a thin seam on blocks that lead to a crack that goe up under a bulge then works left and up over another (crux) bulge.

content.description:
Even the Queen of Egypt fell off the tinies at the crux of this route.  

  Technical devious moves with precise footwork.    Technique will serve you better than brawn on this one.
content.location: Next route to the right of Book of John.  Follow seam past 3 bolts to a roof.  Then pull up into fun climbing through the shallow slot.

content.description: Start looks a little ugly as a good bit of loose rock fell off.  What is left is solid and the climbing is fun from start to finish.
content.location: First bolted line left of the arete on the east face.  Climbs face up to some right angling cracks.

content.description: Classic arete climbing on thin holds.  Just when you think you have it the final bulge will keep you from the temple.
content.location: Obvious arete that is just right of center on the east (toward the road) face.  Start in the 5.9 corner but immediately step left to the arete.

content.description: Steep and a little sharp in places.  Bakerized (bolted in a way that encourages you to climb a certain piece of rock) in two places, the middle and the top.  If you don't want to climb over the bolts feel free to wander it will still be 10+.
content.location: Walk around the left side of the formation to the back.  The right hand route on the uphill side of the pinnacle is this climb.

content.description: Neat looking line that is way more in your face than you might think.  Pro is good but hard to place at times.  Be sure there is no vegetation growing out of the crack as you will need to place pro in those spots.  Pretty fun climbing and if the pro was easier to place I would call it a great climb.  Hanging on to place gear will work you as much as the climbing.
content.protection: double rack to purple camalot and maybe one green.  I used brass nuts as well.  We used the anchors for I Want My Mummy to lower off.
content.location: Just left of Guardians Edge.  Crack climb out the left side of a small roof.

climbs.name: Diehedral
climbs.fa: Charlie Rollins, Josh Toefield, Bill Atkinson,'79

content.description: Nice corner with cracks and good pro.
content.location: Corner just right of the attractive arete that is a bit right of center on the east face.

content.description: A couple of bolts lead to the gear protected crux of Never Again then continues right along a weakness that leads to a single bolt protected crux.
content.location: Two bolts on a slab just left of a thin seam. The seam is just left of the start of Never Again.

content.description: Short hard start to an interesting traverse and a short crack to finish.  More fun than expected.
content.protection: Two bolts a red camalot on down to 2 double zero TCU's and small stoppers which will work in the crack right above the bulge.
content.location: Right most route starts from a small platform of rock.  Two bolts the second drilled straight up into the bulge.

content.description: Slab, laybacking, roof, bulge, steep face and more slab.  Everything but jamming.
content.location: The left side of the Sphinx is dominated by a large oval face.  Below this is a big left pointing flake with a half moon shaped hueco under the roof the flake forms.  Starts left of a thin crack/seam on a light colored slab.

content.description: Sustained, fun climbing and a variety of moves.  Moves left into the corner of DIEHEDRAL 5.9 for a body length or so then underclings a flake back right then up the face.
content.location: Obvious dihedral just right of the 5.9 trad corner called DIEHEDRAL.

content.description: A small crag that had only four routes until recently.  The east face is warm on a sunny day in the winter as is the west face later in the day.  Few have climbed here as the approach before the fire was pretty nasty with a lot of Manzanita.  Rock is a little sharp as most rock in the Windy Point area is.  Some of the new routes have some short sections of grainy stuff but that should go away with a little climbing activity.
